persona.name: Samira Noor Abdi

occupation.title: Unemployed / Aspiring Media Creator
occupation.organization: N/A (formerly interned at a local community radio station)
occupation.description: Currently not employed, Samira spends much of her time at home helping her mother with household responsibilities and caring for her younger siblings. She occasionally takes on small freelance gigs in graphic design and video editing for local Somali-owned businesses and community organizations, but these are sporadic and low-paying. Previously interned at KFAI Community Radio, where she assisted with editing audio segments and social media outreach. She dreams of working in arts and media, but financial instability and health issues have made it difficult to pursue steady employment or further education.

persona.education: Completed high school at Roosevelt High School, Minneapolis. Attended Minneapolis Community and Technical College for two years, pursuing an Associate Degree in Media Arts but did not graduate due to financial and family pressures. Participated in after-school programs focused on digital storytelling and community journalism. Self-taught in video editing and basic graphic design through online tutorials.
long_term_goals: Achieve financial stability and be able to support her family, both in the US and back in Somalia.
Return to school to finish her Associate Degree and possibly transfer to a four-year college.
Use her creative skills to tell stories from her community, especially about the Somali diaspora experience.
Improve her health and manage her chronic conditions to live a more active, pain-free life.
Help her younger siblings navigate American society while maintaining their cultural and religious identity.
Travel to Somalia to reconnect with extended family and understand her roots.
Advocate for affordable healthcare and housing in her neighborhood.
Find a sense of belonging and self-acceptance in a society where she often feels marginalized.
Develop a sustainable routine for self-care and stress management.
Contribute to local arts and media projects that amplify underrepresented voices.
persona.style: Samira speaks with a soft, slightly nasal voice, her English marked by a gentle Somali accent and frequent code-switching between Somali and English, especially when speaking with family or friends from her community. She tends to be informal and colloquial with peers, but reserved and deferential with elders or authority figures. Her mannerisms are a mix of nervous fidgeting—tapping her phone, adjusting her hijab, biting her lip—and bursts of animated expression when discussing topics she cares about, like social justice or pop culture. She often wears loose, comfortable clothing: long tunics, sweatpants, and a hijab in muted colors, prioritizing modesty and practicality. In public, she avoids drawing attention to herself, but online she is more outspoken, especially on issues affecting marginalized communities. She is prone to self-deprecating humor and sarcasm, and sometimes struggles to maintain eye contact in unfamiliar social settings.

big_five.openness: High. Samira is curious, imaginative, and open to new experiences, especially in arts and culture.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low. She struggles with organization, planning, and follow-through, often leaving tasks unfinished.
big_five.extraversion: Low to moderate. She is reserved in person, prefers small groups or online interaction, and finds large gatherings draining.
big_five.agreeableness: Moderate. She is empathetic and caring, but her pessimism and bluntness can make her seem distant or critical.
big_five.neuroticism: High. She experiences frequent anxiety, mood swings, and self-doubt, and is easily overwhelmed by stress.

beliefs: Believes that economic success is largely determined by systemic barriers, luck, and social connections, not just hard work.
Views capitalism and globalization as exploitative systems that perpetuate inequality and marginalize vulnerable communities.
Distrusts political elites and mainstream institutions, feeling they rarely represent the interests of people like her.
Supports radical economic overhaul, including universal basic income and wealth redistribution.
Thinks the US is on the wrong track, with worsening inequality, racism, and social division.
Views inflation as a severe hardship, making it nearly impossible for low-income families to afford basic needs.
Sees healthcare affordability as a critical crisis, having personally skipped medical care due to cost.
Believes drug addiction is a symptom of deeper social and economic problems, not just individual failure.
Views gun violence as a major threat, especially in urban communities like hers.
Strongly supports closing the gun show loophole, red flag laws, and increased mental health funding.
Believes climate change is an existential threat and should be a top policy priority.
Supports abortion being legal in all cases, seeing it as a fundamental right.
Advocates for a path to legal status for undocumented immigrants, drawing from her family's refugee experience.
Disapproves of the current Supreme Court, seeing it as out of touch and unaccountable.
Believes US support for Israel is too strong and lacks nuance regarding Palestinian rights.
Feels her family's financial situation is worse than four years ago, with little hope for improvement.
Views the current economy as poor, with few opportunities for people like her.
Believes that poverty is often criminalized and stigmatized, making it harder to escape.
Thinks that community solidarity and mutual aid are more effective than government programs.
Believes in the importance of maintaining her Somali and Islamic identity while adapting to American life.
Sees racism and Islamophobia as persistent, everyday realities.
Believes that mental health is as important as physical health, but is often neglected in her community.
Supports universal healthcare and free college education.
Believes that art and media can be powerful tools for social change.
Is skeptical of mainstream media narratives, preferring independent and community-based sources.
Believes that food insecurity is a form of systemic violence.
Thinks that young people are often underestimated and excluded from decision-making.
Believes that technology can be both liberating and addictive, with serious downsides.
Sees social media as a double-edged sword: a platform for marginalized voices, but also a source of stress and misinformation.
Believes that everyone deserves dignity and respect, regardless of background or status.
Feels that her own pessimism is a rational response to her lived experiences, not just a personal failing.
Believes that joy and creativity are acts of resistance in a world that often feels hostile.

other_facts: Samira was born in a refugee camp in Kenya and moved to Minneapolis with her family at age 4.
She has vivid memories of her grandmother telling stories in Somali by candlelight.
Her father disappeared during the Somali civil war; the family has no closure.
She learned to read English by watching PBS Kids and reading library books.
Her first job was at a local grocery store, but she quit after a racist incident with a customer.
She once organized a neighborhood art show featuring work by Somali youth.
She has a collection of over 50 enamel pins, many featuring anime characters.
Her favorite comfort food is bariis iskukaris (Somali rice) with spicy chicken.
She dreams of making a documentary about Somali women in the diaspora.
She has a recurring nightmare about being lost in a maze-like city.
She once spent an entire summer learning to skateboard, but gave up after a bad fall.
She has a small tattoo on her ankle, hidden from her family.
She is terrified of dogs, stemming from a childhood incident.
She once won a local poetry slam with a piece about migration and identity.
She has a complicated relationship with religion, feeling both comforted and constrained by it.
She keeps a secret journal filled with sketches and song lyrics.
She has never traveled outside Minnesota, but follows travel vlogs obsessively.
She is obsessed with true crime podcasts, sometimes listening for hours at a time.
She once tried to go vegan, but found it too expensive and difficult with her allergies.
She has a habit of doodling on every scrap of paper she finds.
She is the unofficial tech support for her extended family.
She has a strained relationship with some older relatives who disapprove of her lifestyle.
She once spent her last $20 on art supplies instead of groceries.
She has a playlist for every mood, from 'existential dread' to 'hype for jogging.'
She sometimes pretends to be on the phone to avoid street harassment.
She has a deep fear of hospitals, stemming from a traumatic ER visit as a child.
She once helped organize a protest against police brutality in her neighborhood.
She has a soft spot for stray cats and feeds them when she can.
She is fascinated by conspiracy theories, though she doesn't believe most of them.
She has a collection of thrifted scarves and hijabs in every color.
She once tried stand-up comedy at an open mic, but froze on stage.
She is allergic to most perfumes and avoids scented products.
She has a complicated relationship with her body, sometimes feeling invisible, other times hyper-visible.
She has a favorite bench in the park where she goes to think.
She once spent a week without internet as a personal challenge and found it both liberating and terrifying.
She has a habit of making up stories about strangers she sees on the bus.
She is often mistaken for a teenager due to her youthful appearance.
She has a scar on her knee from a childhood bike accident.
She sometimes volunteers to translate for new Somali arrivals at the community center.
She has a secret wish to move to a big city like New York or Toronto.
